title: Extraction of RNA from Wastewater Primary Solids Using a Direct Extraction Method for Downstream SARS-CoV-2 RNA Quantification
title_html: Extraction of RNA from Wastewater Primary Solids Using a Direct Extraction Method for Downstream SARS-CoV-2 RNA Quantification

protocol.title: Extraction of RNA from Wastewater Primary Solids Using a Direct Extraction Method for Downstream SARS-CoV-2 RNA Quantification
protocol.title_html: Extraction of RNA from Wastewater Primary Solids Using a Direct Extraction Method for Downstream SARS-CoV-2 RNA Quantification

source.description:
Centrifuge at
.

source.body: Bring the centrifuge rotor to the BSC before loading or opening.

source.description: Decant the supernatant into an empty 50 mL falcon tube or larger container. Record the weight and volume of the remaining solids.

source.body: Discard liquid as biohazard waste.

source.description:
Transfer solids for percent solids measurement: Transfer a generous (~
) aliquot of the solid fraction onto a pre-weighed aluminum weigh dish. The aluminum weigh dish should be used directly out of the oven and not allowed to rehydrate. Record the total weight of the weigh dish before covering with aluminum and transferring to the oven to measure dry weight following EPA method Method 106.3. (Page 62)
Link to EPA method. See page 62.

source.body: If there is less than 2 g of solids available, % solids may be performed with a smaller aliquot.

source.description:
Aliquot solids as follows into tarred or pre-weighed tubes using a sterile spatula. Note exact mass aliquoted, with a target range from
to
.

Individually spike each sample that has been aliquoted in a 15mL PowerBead tube with 20 µL BCoV stock. Pipet the spike directly into the solids and mix well with a spatula to homogenize. Equilibrate the sample at 4°C for 1 hour.

source.body: Vials of BCoV vaccine should be rehydrated with molecular grade water before use via needle and syringe, and the solution may be stored at 4°C. For each batch of BCoV, a known dilution in PBS should be processed and analyzed in order to determine the concentration spiked

source.description:
Store samples in PowerBead tubes at
until extraction. Archive samples in cryovials at
.

Prepare for extractions using the RNeasy PowerSoil Total RNA kit to extract and isolate viral RNA into 100uL of eluent. This extract can be used for one step ddPCR or reverse transcribed for qPCR.
Before starting
  • Prepare a sterile workspace
  • Heat Solution IRS at
  • until any precipitate dissolves.
  • Wear RNase-free gloves at all times and remove RNase from the work area.
Heat Solution IRS at
until any precipitate dissolves.

source.body: All sample processing must occur in the biosafety cabinet until the bead beating step is completed. After bead beating, cells have been completely lysed and the samples are considered non-infectious.

source.description:
Remove samples from the freezer and place
. Samples do not need to be thawed before processing. Use Solution IRS while it is still warm.

For processing samples already in PowerBead tube
Add
of PowerBead Solution,
of Solution SR1 and
of Solution IRS directly to the tube containing the sample. Vortex the tube vigorously to suspend the solids.

source.body: If the sample is not in a powerbead tube, perform step 11 in the sample tube, transferring the entire mixture to the PowerBead tube prior to step 12. If a large amount of residual solids remain in the tube after step 11, perform step 4 in two “washes” of 1.75 mL each phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol. If a disposable spatula was used, the spatula can also be rinsed in this solution as well.

source.description:
Cap and vortex the PowerBead Tube to mix until the biphasic layer disappears. Place the PowerBead Tube on a Vortex Adapter and vortex at maximum speed for
.

Remove the PowerBead Tube and centrifuge at
for
at
. After centrifugation, two or three phases may be visible. Total nucleic acids are retained in the upper aqueous phase.
Transfer the upper aqueous phase  to a clean 15 ml Collection Tube.  Take care not to transfer material from the lower phases.

source.body: After transferring the upper aqueous, the remaining fractions can be discarded as BSL2 waste.

source.description:
Add
of Solution SR3 to the aqueous phase and vortex to mix. Incubate at
for
and then centrifuge at
for
at
.
Transfer the supernatant, without disturbing the pellet, to a new 15 ml Collection Tube.

Add
of Solution SR4 to the supernatant in the Collection Tube and invert or vortex to mix.
Incubate at
for
.

source.body: Samples can also be incubated at , to continue procedure on the next day.

source.description:
Centrifuge at
for
.

Decant the supernatant and invert the 15 ml Collection Tube on a paper towel for
.

source.body: Check that the pellet seems to be firmly in the bottom of the tube - if so, you can carefully pour off the supernatant to decant.

source.description:
Shake Solution SR5 to mix and add
to the 15 ml Collection Tube. Resuspend the pellet completely by repeatedly pipetting or vortexing.

source.body: The pellet will be difficult to resuspend. Place the tube in a heat block or water bath at for , followed by vortexing and/or pipetting up and down. Repeat until the pellet is resuspended. When the pellet is fully re-suspended, the solution will appear as a relatively opaque homogenous cloudy yellow-white solution. Continue heating and vortexing until no visible precipitates remain. Failing to fully re-suspend the pellet will result in large downstream losses of nucleic acids.

source.description: Prepare one JetStar Mini Column from the RNeasy kit for each RNA isolation sample. Remove the cap of a 15 ml Collection Tube (provided) and place the JetStar Mini Column inside it. The column will hang in the Collection Tube.
Add the RNA isolation sample from Step 21 onto the JetStar Mini Column and allow it to gravity flow through the column into the 15 ml Collection Tube.

source.body: Expect the flow-rate through the column to be slow (and highly variable between samples) - reserve enough time accordingly. If possible, allow samples to flow through under gravity only. If time to flow exceeds 1 hr, add positive pressure to the column using a syringe plunger. Do not force the flow at a rate of >1 drop per second.

source.description:
Add
of Solution SR5 to the JetStar Mini Column and allow it to completely gravity flow into the 15 ml Collection Tube.

source.body: Apply positive pressure with syringe plunger to samples that are stalled. Do not force the flow at a rate of >1 drop per second.

source.description:
Transfer the JetStar Mini Column to a new 15 ml Collection Tube. Shake Solution SR6 to mix and then add
to the JetStar Mini Column to elute the bound RNA. Allow Solution SR6 to gravity flow into the 15 ml Collection Tube.

source.body: Apply positive pressure with syringe plunger to samples that are stalled. Do not force the flow at a rate of >1 drop per second.

source.description:
Transfer the eluted RNA to a 2.2 ml Collection Tube. Add
of Solution SR4. Invert at least once to mix and incubate at
for a minimum of
.

source.body: Samples can also be incubated at , to split continue the procedure on the next day.

source.description:
Centrifuge the 2.2 ml Collection Tube at
for
to pellet the RNA.

Decant the supernatant and invert the 2.2 ml Collection Tube onto a paper towel for
to air dry the pellet.

Resuspend the RNA pellet in
of Solution SR7. Observe the pellet carefully to make sure it is fully re-suspended. The RNA is now ready for downstream applications.

source.body: Observe the base of the tube while slowly rotating the sample - there should not appear to be any material adhered to the side or base of the tube, and the solution should flow smoothly.

source.description: Use the Zymo OneStep PCR Inhibitor Removal Columns to remove inhibitors that were co-concentrated with the nucleic acids from the extracts to prevent downstream issues.

Centrifuge collection tubes in columns at
for
.
Discard collection tube with flow through and load column into a labeled 1.5mL LoBind tube.

Add the full volume of RNA/DNA extract (
) to each column.

Centrifuge LoBind tubes with column at
for

This extract can be used for cDNA synthesis or as template for a one-step PCR reaction. Immediately perfom Nanodrop analysis, Qubit analysis, and/or reverse transcriptase if desired, or store eluent at
for later use.

One 2g aliquot can be place directly into a 15 mL PowerBead tubes from RNeasy PowerSoil Total RNA extraction kit to prepare for extraction. Depending on the number of replicates required, additional aliquots can also be placed in PowerBead tubes for extraction.

Additional 2g aliquots may be placed in as many 5mL cryovials as possible for storage at
.

Load
samples of primary sludge at a time into the centrifuge rotor. Balance with equally weighted tubes filled with water.

Day before sample processing:
Thaw sample
at
. Record the weight and volume of the sample.
Day of sample processing:
Place aluminum dishes in oven
before use
Set centrifuge temperature to
before use

Add
of phenol/chlorogorm/isoamyl alcohol (pH 6.5–8.0, not included in kit) to the sample tube. Vortex vigorously.

Add
of Solution SR5 to the JetStar Mini Column. Allow it to completely gravity flow through the column and collect in the 15 ml Collection Tube.

source.body: Do not allow the column to dry out before loading sample in the next step.

source.description:
Place one column into one collection tube for each sample you need and add
of Prep solution to each column.

description:
Overview

This SOP describes pre-analytical procedures to be followed for the isolation and identification of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in primary settled solids samples from wastewater treatment plants. This protocal should be paired with our digital PCR protocal.
The protocol follows the approximate workflow:
  1. Separate and aliquot sample (~4 hrs)
  2. Spike with BCoV (~1 hr)
  3. Extract RNA (~ 12 hours total, may be split into 2-3 steps/days)
  4. Inhibitor removal (~1 hr)

Biosafety Concerns

Concentration and extraction procedures that utilize raw samples must adhere to strict Biosafety Level 2+ procedures. These procedures should be performed in a dedicated room. Downstream products may be handled using standard laboratory safety guidelines.
This protocol was developed by Stephanie Loeb, Katy Graham, Marlene Wolfe, Krista Wigginton, and Alexandria Boehm at Stanford University and University of Michigan.
